{{MAMBOTOC_SMALL}} There are a number of different user types in Mambo, and it can be useful to know that privileges and rights each user type has. Sometimes, you may want a user to be able to write content but not publish it - there are user types for this.
=== Guest ===
The guest user is anyone visiting your website that has not logged in yet. Your site visitors can view all content and utilize all feature of the website that are available to all users including guests.
All other user levels have the same privileges as the guest user along with additional capabilities.
== Frontend ==
=== Registered user ===
The registered users will have access to all menu items in the class "public" and "registered". The user will also have access to edit its own user details such as password and real name
=== Author ===
Access to the "new" buttons that shows under the articles when browsing a content category. Can't publish new articles, and cannot edit existing ones.
=== Editor ===
Can edit already published articles, as well as create new ones. Cannot publish articles.
=== Publisher ===
A publisher can create items, save them and publish them - a publisher can in other words publish articles on the front page without any approval from admininstrators.
== Backend ==
=== Manager ===
''Access these menu-items'':
*Home *Site **Media Manager **Preview **Statistics *Menu (with all available menus) *Content (all content) *Help
''These Quickicons are available'':
*Help *All Content Items *Static Content Manager *Front page Manager *Section Manager *Category Manager
=== Administrator ===
''Access these menu-items'':
*Home *Site **Media Manager **Preview **Statistics **Trash manager **User manager *Menu (with all available menus) *Content (all content) *Components (all components) *Modules *Mambots *Installers *Help
''Quickicons available'':
All except from Global Configuration.
=== Super Administrator ===
All links and quickicons available - can edit, modify and change every option available. Has access to database functions.

{{MAMBOTOC_SMALL}}
Content can be created or edited from both the frontend of your Mambo website or from the Administration backend. In both cases it is required that you have logged in. For basic explanations of content items, see [[Mambo_Open_Source/Content_basics|content basics-article]]. You can also read the [[Mambo_Open_Source/Administration_basics|administration basics article]]
===From frontend===
Browse to the ''content'' category were you want the article - e.g. "news > latest news". Here you can see a list of all the content items in the category, or a pagination or something similar. Somewhere on '''this page''' a "new"-icon shows up. Press this, and you enter the "new content item"-section.
Write the content as usual . On the bottom of this page, below the text fields, you can see some tabs and some parameters. Enter the parameters here as usual.
Press the save-button at the top of the page.
===From backend===
At the main page of the backend (the home-link), use the "All content items"-button in the quickicons-section. Here you get a list of all the content items available. Press the "new" button in the toolbar.
This takes you to the standard inputbox-view. Write content, and choose content section and category in the drop-down menus to the right of the items "title" and "alias"-fields.
The parameters box appear on the right of the inputs, and this should be configured the way you want it to.

Give me comments and feedbacks here! Press the + icon to the right of the "edit this page" tab on the top of this page. == Reverting page move vandalism == The way to revert page-move vandalism is to ''move the page back to its original name'', not to copy &paste the original page onto the new one. '''Copy&paste "moves" are bad. Don't do them.''' Unfortunately, you've stopped other people from fixing the vandalism properly, and now we have to wait for an administrator to delete the new page so that [[Wikibooks:Ass Pus in Progress]] can be moved back to its original location. Please don't do that again. [[User:Uncle G|Uncle G]] 09:26, 24 Apr 2005 (UTC) :It's not so bad. The deletion is done, and the page moved. [[User:Gentgeen|Gentgeen]] 09:47, 24 Apr 2005 (UTC) == Wikiversity School of Music == Please see my comments on the [Wikiversity:School of Music] page. While the content you've created is good, it does not belong within the SOM namespace, it is a textbook you've written, not a Wikiversity section. Jamesbooker == Moving vs Removing == Hi, You just removed ''global configuration''. maybe better idea could be to move to better place? --[[User:AndriuZ|AndriuZ]] 23:54, 27 Jun 2005 (UTC) :Hi, :I removed it as it wasnt a part of the installation. I am sorry if that might seemed harsh, i don't want to scare away contributors, so thanks for contacting me! I have added an article for the global configuration under the miscellaneous chapter, and a new configuration-category. *[[Mambo_Open_Source/Global configuration|A link to the article]]. :Please feel free to do more contributions - and i will try to take it to the discussion page before simply deleting stuff.. =) :--[[User:August]] 00:01, 28 Jun 2005 :: Hi, I have nothing against discussions, but time is passing :-) The same was my first idea ''Category:mambo open source'', but it is too long for inserting... so then I reconsidered when did 2 levels of Categories, see : :: - {{bad link|Category:Information Technology}}, {{bad link|Category:How-tos}} - only for first Article [[Mambo Open Source]] :: - {{bad link|Category:MOS}} - for all other articles... ::Let's move this discussion to Mambo page? --[[User:AndriuZ|AndriuZ]] 14:13, 28 Jun 2005 (UTC) :::All this sound very good to me! Are you planning to write some content in this book too? I would very much like that, you'd be the first one besides me to acualt write an article here - all edits in this book that i didn't do so far were corrections of typos (exept from some additions in the resources-page). :::--August 15:18, 28 Jun 2005 (UTC) == book rating. == Ok, it's new and not widely used but there is a template to rate the books: {{stage|75%|Apr 3, 2005}} and {{stage short|75%|Apr 3, 2005}}. Important - in the dynamic wiki environment - is the date when the rating was issued. === Explanation === In the beginning the rating of pages was just done by a small icon (you know 0%.png, 25%.png) etc. pp. and most pages are still rated this way. However it is suggested that any new rating is done with the templates above. This templates also show the date when the rating was done. See [[Help:Development_stages]] for more details on how to rate a book. --[[User:Krischik|Krischik]] 05:26, 29 Jun 2005 (UTC) === What should we do? === I am aware of this new system, as I just implented it into the norwegian wikibooks. But i had no idea it was new! Anyway, should I just go ahead and use those templates? And rate it to 50%? === Yes === Shure, i.E. I changed all ratings for [[Programming:Ada]] - at least when I found them. === It's done === Fixed the rating of the mambo open source book in the it-bookshelf template. --August 14:26, 30 Jun 2005 (UTC) ==Gambling to a Million== *There are other one-page wikibooks, like [[How to Tie a Tie]]; furthermore, is the [[Jokebook]] really educational? [[User:Charlie123|Charlie123]] 5 July 2005 16:27 (UTC) ::Well, i think that books like ''how to tie a tie'' and ''gambling to a million'' really should go away and be deleted - they are small and un needed, and as you can see, both have now been removed. None of those could have been called a book, ad it was one page only. If you had created a book, and started on a book, that could expand and be contributed to, and not a single page, chances are that no one would have deleted it. But one page only books, that you actually claimed to be 100% complete, has nothing in the wikibooks to do. ::Actually, I urge you to create a book about gambling that is a book, and not one page. If you do that, i will support it. I agree that a book about gambling, and the jokebook are not for educational puspouses, but as long as they are used and contributed to i find them very useful to have at the wikibooks. ::--August 5 July 2005 22:21 (UTC) == Table of contents == see answer moved to [[Talk:Mambo Open Source/Table of contents]] == discuss things before doing them == * on subject : ''discuss things before doing them'' - I fully agree for big rearengements (if we will agree a time for responce, for example 3 days?), but for the other things - its really takes less time to make improvement without discussion. You and me could easily track changes... and ''revert'' if really don't like --[[User:AndriuZ|AndriuZ]] 13:58, 11 July 2005 (UTC) * Hi, I did translation about some guy impression , see [[User:AndriuZ/SandboxMamboMambo4.5.3]] --[[User:AndriuZ|AndriuZ]] 20:54, 11 July 2005 (UTC) == Images == As you can see at the top of this page, "All unlicensed images uploaded to wikibooks before November 1, 2006 will soon be deleted." You have uploaded images and some of them are untagged. You can see them [http://tools.wikimedia.de/~daniel/WikiSense/UntaggedImages.php?wikifam=.wikibooks.org&wikilang=en&order=img_user_text&max=500&img_user_text=August&grouped= here]. Please review them and add appropriate tags. If you have any questions, feel free to [[User talk:Think Fast|ask me]]. --[[User:Think Fast|Think Fast]] 04:37, 13 November 2006 (UTC) == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called August. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name August~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
23:00, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

{{MAMBOTOC_SMALL}} Some browsers, among those Internet Explorer, doesn't show transparency on transparent png-images. Instead, a grey colour is shown. This fixes the problem, but only for Internet Explorer (Win). NB! This problem doesn't affect Firefox, Opera and Netscape. ==Why png?== Many people say that one can use gif images - both Internet Explorer, Firefox, Opera and all major browsers support transparency in gif images. The thing is that transparency is pretty bad and lossy in quality compared to png images. Regular transparency with hard edges are no problem, but shadow and transparent gradients are no good with gif. Png can do this without problems, tough, only that Internet Explorer (Win) doesn't support it (IE for Mac does). ==How to solve the problem== ===Adding code to the relevant page=== There is a simple modification that needs to be done with the template(s) the site is using. This can be done from mambo, as long as the appropriate files are writable. Log in to the backend. Choose "Site > Template Manager > Site templates". Choose the template that should be modified (naturally the standard template) and choose "edit" in the toolbar. On the top of this document, add this line:
Then upload the "ie_png.php"-file in the "includes" folder of your mambo installation. Here are the file: [[Media:http://www.mambonordic.com/downloads/ie_png.zip]] ===Fixing the images themselves=== Internet Explorer (Win) can actually render some png-files - those with 256 colors. These images can contain any color in the HEX color scheme, but not more than 256 colors all together within the image. This is more than enough for most cases. Save/render the png images with this attribute, and Internet Explorer will actually render transparency. There are some problems with transparent gradients, as fading shadows etc.

{{MAMBOTOC_SMALL}}
This article '''explains the concept of server side scripting''', which is a key element in mambo.
==What is server side scripting?==
There are two major forms of scripting in web applications. One of them is client side scripting. This is scripts and code that is downloaded to the clients computer and is executed there. A good example of this is JavaScript and Flash. Here scripts are used to create animations, drop-down menus and other functions on the clients computer.
Server side scripting, on the opposite, keeps all the scripts on the server, and they are executed there. In this case, mambo is the script. Basically, the client sends a request to the server. The server, with mambo installed receives this request, and use the scripts on the server to create the page that the user has requested. Then, a finished version of the results of this program is sent to the user, with no scripts in it (exept from the client side scripts that might follow with a mambo site).

{{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Image Textures |next=Quickie Texture }}
{{B3D:N2P/ForVersion|2.70}}
'''Procedural Textures'''
Texturing objects can be broken down into two categories: procedural and image texturing. Procedural texturing makes use of mathematical formulas to generate textures. This is nice because it can be used to make relatively nice looking textures without external images which are very temperamental where you put them. Procedural Textures are all stored in the .blend file. These textures are obviously generated within Blender itself. Image texturing uses images created or captured outside of Blender, either from an image manipulation program such as the Paint.NET, GIMP or Photoshop, or captured on a camera. We have already learned about image texturing, so let's move on to procedural texturing.
'''Current Procedural Textures'''
Blender currently supports many procedural textures, including: Clouds, Marble, Stucci, Wood, Magic, Blend, Noise, Musgrave, Voronoi and DistortedNoise.
==A Simple Wood Texture== Let's define a simple wood texture: * Start a new Blender document containing the default cube. * Select the cube (and nothing else) * Go to the Materials tab [[File:Blender255MaterialContextButton.png]] in the Properties Window, and rename the default "Material" to "Wood Material". Alternatively, delete the default material using the X to the right of the name field and add a new material.
Let's add some color and texture. You can see the results at any time by pressing F12 to re-render the scene.
Start by painting cube a base color using the Wood Material's "diffuse" color: * In the “Material” tab, * Scroll down to the “Diffuse” properties panel and choose a darker brown color e.g. #A57E3F. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV for where brown fits in the color wheel.
Next, let's add a texture to give the material some highlights. * Switch to the “Texture” properties tab [[File:Blender259_Texture_Button.png]], and again rename the default "Tex" to "Wood Texture" or create a new texture. Notice at the very top of the "Texture" tab "Cube > Wood Material > Wood Texture" * Change the Type of the material to “Wood” using the pop-up menu.
The texture sample will show parallel alternating black and white bars that don’t look very woody at all. Never fear! The black regions will be the material's base "diffuse" color. The white regions are like "highlights" that will be painted over the base.
Let's make some improvements to the texture: * While still in the “Textures” tab, * Scroll to the “Wood” properties panel that appears, change the waveform from “Sine” to “Saw”. * In the next row of buttons down, change the type from the default “Bands” to “Ring Noise”. * Increase the Noise Size to 1.0. Now the texture sample should show something resembling wavy tree-rings. If you hit F12 to render now, you will see these rings covering your cube, except a) the colour is wrong, and b) normal wood patterns aren't so nearly circular.
To make the pattern more elongated: * Scroll to the “Mapping” properties panel, * Change the Size X value to 2.0 and Y to 0.4. This squishes the pattern down along the X-axis, and stretches it out along the Y-axis, giving the elliptical tree-ring shapes you commonly see on wood planks and boards.
Hit F12 to render again, and the shape of the texture should be looking a lot more woody now.
The final step is to color the highlights in the texture: * In the “Textures” tab, * Scroll to the “Influence” properties panel further down, * Click on the color swatch, and choose a nice brown colour. For a nicer effect, I chose a very light brown e.g. #DEB887.
The result should look very woody indeed!
[[Image:Blender259WoodTextureSample.png]]
* Remember that you need to Render to see the wood grain on your object.
{{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Image Textures |next=Quickie Texture }}

page.title: Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/The Rusty Ball

revision.text: {{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Basic Carpet Texture |next=Creating Pixar-looking eyes in Blender }} {{B3D:N2P/ForVersion|2.75}} Making objects with image textures is not really hard for simple objects like balls, cubes, and tubes. I'll show you how to do this: [[File:The-rusty-ball.png|300px|right]] # Make a new scene in Blender and delete the default cube. # Add a sphere. Apply a Subsurf modifier and Smooth as we have learned in previous tutorials. # Find a file picture that you want to apply to your object. Check Flickr for something like "rust texture." (If you are going to share it, be sure you check the license of the texture you download.) # IMPORTANT: Sometimes you need a seamless texture. If you are not sure, use a program such as GIMP. Use FILTERS > MAP > MAKE SEAMLESS. Usually this works well but if your texture turns into gorp, try another one. # ('''Noob Note:''' ''Do [http://images.google.com/images?sourceid=navclient&rlz=1T4GGLR_enUS262US264&q=rust%20texture&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&hl=en&tab=wi ''a search for '''Rust Textures''' ''] if you do not have one handy.'') # In the Properties Panel, which by default is the bottom right panel, select the Material icon [[File:Blender268TextureIconMaterial.png]]. # Select NEW or if you already have a material in use, select the + sign to add a new material. Give it a good name like rustyball. # Click on the Texture Icon [[File:Blender268TextureIconBrush.png]]. # Click NEW or if you already have a texture loaded, click on the + to add a new one. Give it a good name like RUST. # The default type is CLOUDS. Pull down the menu and change it to IMAGE OR MOVIE. # Go to the IMAGE section, choose OPEN. New options will become available. (Note: JPGs, PNGs or TGAs are recommended for Blender. Bitmaps tend to get all screwy.) # Under Source: Click the folder icon and navigate to your image. # Scroll down. In the Image Mapping area are some options that you may need to try. If your image is small it may have to be repeated in the X or Y directions. # In the Mapping section (yes, one section is Image Mapping and the other is just Mapping) after Projection, choose the shape closest to your object. If you are using a sphere like the example, then choose ... you guessed it ... SPHERE. * The Preview often looks a bit odd and stripey, but render your project and it should look very nice. * This method works for all sorts of things. Try making a brick wall with a wooden gate using Flickr textures or go back to the Jeep tutorial and put a pattern on your jeep. * You can also render videos onto objects using this method. Just select a movie in the "Load image" dialog and enable the option "Movie" at the textures buttons. NOTE: Blender ONLY works with Full Resolution video, not video which has been compressed using a codec. Most video software will allow you to export video as "'''full frames'''" or "'''no compression'''". Experiment a bit! [[File:RUSTY BALL.jpg|300 px|left|The Rusty Ball]] [[File:Flickr textures brick wall.jpg|left|thumb|400 px|Textures used from Flicker under Creative Commons 2.0 license]][[File:Psychedelic Jeep.png|right|thumb|400 px|Psychedelic Jeep, my own texture such as it may be]] {{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Basic Carpet Texture |next=Creating Pixar-looking eyes in Blender }}

revision.text:
{{B3D:N2P/NAV |next=Beginner Tutorials |previous=Blender Glossary |subcat=Materials }} == '''"Every Single Material Known To Man" Project''' == Want to share your material settings with the world? This is the place! This page is going to be turning from a page to a chapter, but to do that we need your support! If you have an idea for a material, even if you don't know how to make it, just put it in the list to help! Someone out there knows how to make it, and if they come across this page with it listed, they might be willing to share. === Etiquette === *Explain the basics of every material (such as Color, Spec, and shading, but not neccessarily specifics such as Emit or Trans), even if it is with standard "Add New" properties. *IF you provide a picture, explain in the method all details to get us to make ours look the exact same way, do not omit any detail (including anything done in out tabs, or in other categories like Rendering. Also, say if you use something like RayMir or if you have additional lighting or objects to enhance the look!.) *Make sure you explain the "Tab" and the "Category" for a material alterations, because not everyone might know what you mean. Be as formal as possible, categorize and organize, and try using the blender-used words instead of your own lingo, if possible. Example: *Bad explanation:''Set the material's texture's normal to 0.4'' *Good explanation:''Under the "Map To" Tab, Select the "Nor" Slider and set it to 0.4'' *Best explanation: **'''''Map To:''''' **''Output-Nor'' **'''''Nor'''Slider-0.4'' ~~Do NOT replace or delete other people's method on your own. If you believe you have a better way, simply label their explanation "Method A" and create another sub-headline with your method as "Method B" (and so on). If you believe a method is incorrect, insufficiently detailed or plagarism, appeal to the original author (if able) or on the Discussion page and get support for a removal.
~~Do NOT say your material is better than anyone elses-- everyone has a right to their own opinion and preferences --you may say your method is more "detailed" or "memory-efficient" or "adaptable", but DO NOT SLANDER other people's methods.

revision.text: This is Dinero, Col Stewart, interested in all things Wikipedia, ya huurd.

[[Cookbook]] | [[Cookbook:Units of measurement|Units of measurement]]
The '''cm''', is the symbol for centimetre (centimeter in United States spelling), which is an SI unit of measurement for length. It is equal to 1/100 [[Cookbook:m|m]]. There are 2.54 cm per [[Cookbook:Inch|inch]]. There are 10 [[Cookbook:mm|mm]] per cm.
As many recipes have been crudely converted from one system to another, a similarly crude conversion back may yield the original recipe.
{| class="wikitable" |----- ! cm !! inches |----- ||0.25 ||1/10 |----- ||0.3 ||1/8 |----- ||0.5 ||3/16 |----- ||0.5 ||2/10 |----- ||0.6 ||1/4 |----- ||1 ||3/8 |----- ||1.5 ||5/8 |----- ||2 ||3/4 |----- ||2 ||8/10 |----- ||2.5 ||1 |----- ||3 ||1 + 1/8 |----- ||4 ||1 + 1/2 |----- ||5 ||2 |----- ||6 ||2 + 1/3 |----- ||7 ||2 + 3/4 |----- ||8 ||3 + 1/8 |----- ||9 ||3 + 1/2 |----- ||10 ||4 |----- ||11 ||4 + 1/3 |----- ||12 ||4 + 3/4 |----- ||13 ||5 |----- ||14 ||5 + 1/2 |----- ||15 ||6 |----- ||18 ||7 |----- ||19 ||7 + 1/2 |----- ||20 ||8 |----- ||30 ||12 |----- |} [[Category:Cookbook]]

{{unit}}
The '''m''', is the symbol for metre (meter in US spelling), which is the SI base unit of measurement for length. It is equal to 100 [[Cookbook:cm|cm]], which is about 39.37 [[Cookbook:Inch|inches]]. This is roughly 3 and 1/4 feet.

{{cuisine|Argentina}} | [[Cookbook:South American cuisines|South American Cuisines]]
'''Argentina''' uses lots of [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]].

*[[Cookbook:Empanada|Empanada]] *Locro

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ ==0-9== ==A== ;Abscond :The action of bees leave the hive suddenly with few or no remainders. This should not be confused with swarming; it is often due to problems such as poor ventilation, high temperatures, mite problems, pests or other intolerable problems. ;Acarine :A label for infestation of bees by [[Beekeeping/Tracheal Mites| tracheal mites]]. ;AFB : ''see [[Beekeeping/American Foul Brood| American Foul Brood]]'' ;American Foul Brood :A viral disease affecting bee brood, it is highly contagious and has a long life span. See ''[[Beekeeping/American Foul Brood| American Foul Brood]]'' module. ;Apiary :The area or location as to where bees and hives are kept, some times referred to as a beeyard. ;Apiculture :The science and study and possibly art of keeping bees. ;Apiphobia :The acute fear of bees or anything related to bees. See ''[[Beekeeping/Phobias| Phobias]]'' module ;Apis mellifera :The scientific name of the [[Beekeeping/Honey Bee Races#Italian Honey Bee| Italian honey bee]]. ;Apistan :A miticide used to control Varroa mites. ;Apitherapy :A division of therapy that uses bees and bee products for therapeutic and medical purposes. ==B== ;Beebread :Pollen that was collected by bees and then mixed with various solutions including honey which is stored within a cell of the comb. This is a high protein feed for both the developing larva and bees. ;Bee Glue :See Propolis ;Beehaver :Someone who has bees, but is not at the level of manipulation akin to a beekeeper. ;Beekeeper :Someone who keeps bees ;Beeyard :The area or location as to where bees and hives are kept, more properly called an apiary. ;Bee space :The critical space that must be kept to prevent bees from filling the space with propolis or burr comb. The bee space is commonly thought of as a void greater than 1/4in and smaller than 3/8in. The bee space may vary depending on the size of the specific bee or race. ;Beehive :A container used by a beekeeper for the purpose of keeping a colony of bees out of the weather. It is commonly a form of box or crate, but may be a skep, hollowed log, clay pot, etc. Typically but not necessarily, the combs are removable (frames, top bars) to assist management. Unmanaged bees live in a nest. ;Beeswax :A substance that is secreted by glands present on the worker bee. This is the primary building material used by bees, and the main structure of comb. ;Bottom Board :A segment of man made hive that creates the floor of the hive. ''[[Beekeeping/Bottom Board| Bottom Board]]'' module ;Brace Comb :The sections of seemingly random comb that connect hive parts together. Brace Comb is a form of Burr Comb. ;Burr Comb :Any section of comb that is not a part of the main comb piece within the frame or hanging from the top bar. ;Brood :A general term to refer to immature bees, includes egg, larva and pupae. See ''[[Beekeeping/Brood| brood]] module. ;Brood Chamber :Section of the hive where brood is being raised and where the queen would normally be laying eggs. ;Brood Food :A highly nutritious glandular secretion from the [[Beekeeping/Worker Bee| worker bee]] that is used to feed both [[Beekeeping/Brood| brood]] and the [[Beekeeping/Queen Bee| queen]] ;Build Up :The natural seasonal increase of bee population within a colony that coincides with the start of the main nectar flow ==C== ;Capped Brood :Cells on the comb containing bee larvae that is fully enclosed by function of a wax capping. ;Capping : '''1''' A thin layer of wax that covers cells containing [[Beekeeping/Honey| honey]].
'''2''' The thin air permeable layer of wax that covers the cell of bee [[Beekeeping/Brood| brood]]. ;Caste :A name for the existence of different classifications of bees of a specific family. Includes [[Beekeeping/Queen| Queen]], [[Beekeeping/Drone| Drone]] and [[Beekeeping/Worker| Worker]]. ;Chalk Brood :A fungal infection of the [[Beekeeping/Brood| brood]]. See ''[[Beekeeping/Chalk Brood| chalk brood]] module. ;Cell :A single hexagonal prismatic chamber that makes up comb. Cells are used to store honey, pollen, nectar and developing brood. ;Cleansing Flight :The flight made by a bee to cleanse it’s digestive track after a long period of confinement. ;Cluster :'''1''' A mass of bees, often referring to a swarm or collection.
'''2''' The huddling action taken by the bees within a colony during cold weather ;Colony :A collection or family of bees living within a single social unit. ;Comb :A double sided configuration of hexagonal cells made of beeswax or artificial plastic. Used by the bees to store food and raise brood. ;Crush and Strain :Simple technique to extract honey in which combs are gathered in a straining device (kitchen strainer, bucket with holes in the bottom, etc.) which allows honey to drain into a container below. ==D== ;Dance Language :A basis or rudimentary communication used by bees to provide location information of food sources, water sources or possible new home sites. See ''[[Beekeeping/Dance Language| Dance Language]]'' module ;Drawn Comb :Combs which contain completed cells. ;Drifting :The process in which bees join a separate hive other than their own, often due to loss of direction or hive placed too close together. ;Drone :A male bee. See ''[[Beekeeping/Drone| Drone]]'' module ==E== ;EFB :See '''[[Beekeeping/European Foul Brood| European Foul Brood]]''' ;Entrance Reducer: A device used to limit in and out traffic to a hive. See ''[[Beekeeping/Entrance Reducer| Entrance Reducer]]'' module ;European Foul Brood :A viral disease which affects the bee [[Beekeeping/Brood| brood]]. See ''[[Beekeeping/European Foul Brood| European Foul Brood]] module. ;Extraction :Removal of honey from comb. Typically refers to use of an Extractor but also includes non-mechanical methods such as crush and strain. ;Extractor :A centrifugal device in which frames can be drained of honey. See ''[[Beekeeping/Honey Extractor| Honey Extractor]]'' module ==F== ;Feral Bees :Term is used to describe honeybees that are not managed by a beekeeper. ;Feral Hive :Term used to describe a situated colony of feral bees not managed by a beekeeper aka Nest. ;Food Chamber :The segment of the hive that bees used to store pollen, nectar and honey. ;Foulbrood :Generic term to describe bacterial disease that effect only brood and no adult bees. ;Foundation :A thin sheet of wax or plastic that is embossed to be used as a guide for comb creation by the bees. See ''[[Beekeeping/Foundation| Foundation]]'' module ;Frame :A rectangular segment made of four slats of wood that was made to contain comb. See ''[[Beekeeping/Frame| Frame]]'' module ;Fumadil B :see ''Fumagillin''. ;Fumagillin :An antimicrobial compound used to control [[Beekeeping/Nosema| Nosema]] which is sold under the trade name of ''Fumadil B''. ==G== ;Guard Bee :A bee which remains at the entrance of a hive protecting it from invaders. ;Guarding :The action of a bee which detects invaders and examines entering bees. ==H== ;Hive :Home site for an individual colony of managed bees ;Hive Body :A segment of the hive that creates a chamber for the building of comb and storage of collected resources. See ''[[Beekeeping/Hive Body| Hive Body]]'' module ;Hive Tool :A bladed pry bar used by the beekeeper to maintain and manage a hive. See ''[[Beekeeping/Hive Tool| Hive Tool]]'' module ;Honey Flow :A period of time when an abundance of nectar is available to be collected and converted into honey. ;Honey Comb :Comb that has been nearly or completely filled with honey. ==I== ;Inner Cover :A narrow piece of wood that fits over the upper most hive body and bellow an external cover. See ''[[Beekeeping/Inner Cover| Inner Cover]]'' module ==J== ==K== ;KTBH :A Kenya Top Bar Hive has sloping sides. ==L== ;Langstroth :Modern hive management originated in the writings of Langstroth who recognized the significance of bee space and box sizes of standardized dimensions. Efforts to improve on the original have led to size variations between and within countries but the principles of beespace remain the same. ;Larva :The second stage of development in the life cycle of the bee. ;Laying Worker :An unfertilized, non queen female bee that is capable of laying drone eggs. This is often the result of a hive remaining queenless for a period of time. ==M== ;Malnourished Hive :A colony of bees that lacking the proper nutritional requirements to produce brood. ;Marked Queen :A queen bee that has been marked with a spot of paint or had a disk adhered to her abdomen. ;Miticide :A chemical or biological agent which is applied to a colony to control parasitic mites. ==N== ;Nectar :A food source high in carbohydrates, which occurs naturally in the nectarines of a flower. ;Nectarflow :The mass gathering of nectar from flowers by bees. ;Nest :An unmanaged colony of bees. Often found in the hollow of a tree, wall partition, attic, etc. as the preferred space is dark with a small entrance which is easy to protect. On occasion, European bees will build a nest in a thick shrub or tree. ;Nosema :An illness that effects the digestive track in bees. See ''[[Beekeeping/Nosema| Nosema]]'' module ;Nuc :See Nucleus Hive ;Nucleus Hive :A small colony of bees housed within a smaller hive container. ;Nuptial Flight :The mating flight taken by a queen to mate with a variety of drones. ;Nurse Bee :Young hive bound bee that feeds and cares for larva. ==O== ==P== ;Pheromone :A chemical scent produced to establish a basic form of communication or to stimulate a response. See ''[[Beekeeping/Pheromones| Pheromones]]'' module ;Pollen :The powdery substance produced by the male segment of a flower. See ''[[Beekeeping/Pollen| pollen]]'' module. ;Propolis :A sticky resinous material that bees collect from plants and use to strengthen hive comb and fill cracks within the hive. Often referred to as bee glue. See ''[[Beekeeping/Propolis| Propolis]]'' module ;Pupa :The final stage in a brood bee’s metamorphosis. ==Q== ;Queen :The fertile female bee that one mated should be capable of producing male and female offspring. See ''[[Beekeeping/Queen| Queen]]'' module ;Queen Excluder :A device used to prevent the larger queen bee from passing. See ''[[Beekeeping/Queen Excluder| Queen Excluder]]'' module ;Queen Right :A term used to describe a hive or colony of bees that has a producing queen. ;Queen Substance :The pheromone produced by the queen bee that alerts a colony to the fact that it is Queen Right. ==R== ;Royal Jelly :A substance produced by worker bees to feed to youngest brood and to the queen brood throughout its immature life. ==S== ;Scout Bee :A bee which is responsible for locating a new home site location for a swarm of bees. ;Stinger :The defense mechanism of a bee that is capable of releasing venom in to its victim. ;Stray honeybees :Honeybees that are not under the control of a beekeeper aka Feral. ;Supercedeure :The natural process of a colony of bees replacing its queen with a new queen. ;Supering :The act and process of addend hive bodies to a hive in an effort to collect excess harvestable honey. ;Swarm :A collection of bees that is currently without a home site and looking for a new one. ==T== ;TBH :The Top Bar Hive is a method to manage bees with removable combs which rely on top bars rather than frames for the combs. There is usually no allowance for bee space so the bars represent a continuous cover. There are no standard dimensions as there are for Langstroth hives. See also KTBH, TTBH ;Terramycin :An antibiotic used for the treatment of bacterial disease. ;TTBH :A Tanzanian Top Bar Hive has rectangular sides. ==U== ==V== ==W== ;Winter Cluster :A tightly packed cluster of bees that forms to maintain warmth during the colder winter months. ;Worker :An unfertilizable female bee that constitutes as the majority of a colony’s population. The worker has the responsibility of all hive and foraging tasks. See ''[[Beekeeping/Worker| Worker]]'' module ==X== ==Y== ==Z== {{BookCat}}

We definitely need to reorganize this page. The size of the page is getting unfriendly.. [[User:Lynx7725|Lynx7725]] 03:18, 21 Apr 2005 (UTC)
